Title: Release of fuel oil and heating fuel from the pipe-line connecting the coastal oil storage facility and the thermal power plant
LessonsLearned: Concerning repair operations the operator has included in the parts management system all available elements to reduce the impact of new leakages.<br><br>From the material aspect,:<br>- the method adopted to identify failures (current leakage detection) has proven to be effective and it is planned to extend the use of this method also to the other pipe-lines in the area affected by the rise of brackish water; in accordance with the results, it is planned to integrate this kind of control as well as the frequency in the context of an amendment to the Monitoring and Response Plans which will&nbsp; also provide for the regular control of the pipeline systems.<br><br>Depending on the results of the tests the hypothesis of replacing entire pipe-lines or certain sections will be discussed. <br>The mutual exchange of information between the Municipality and the operators was organised in the presence of the competent authorities DDAF; DDASS; DRIRE.<br><br>In the context of a better information on hazardous underground structures an inter-organisational geographical information system (GIS) is under development; it will inform civil engineering companies about the pathways of underground pipe-lines and underground electric lines.<br>&nbsp; <br>
EmergencyResponce_Descr: The Monitoring and Response Plan was released and the following measures were taken.<br>- filling of the pipe-line with water without pressure<br>- pumping of the liquid fraction of the product from the ground surface<br>- search of the leakage point<br>- stripping of the polluted soil surface (approximately 250 m3) and temporary storage in an hydrocarbon-proof area.<br><br>The operator of the thermal power-plant performed apart from the above mentioned first measures 8 test drills and installed three piezometers in order to outline the polluted area. The method employed is failure points identification by current leakage detection. <br><br>The control of the 7430 meters long pipe-line was performed. The method employed is failure points identification by current leakage detection. 17 failure points were found in the pipeline section named as "upstream" section&nbsp; corresponding to the section between the coast and the intermediary storage facility, and 9 failure points were found in the pipeline section called "downstream" corresponding to the section between the intermediate storage facility and the power plant .<br><br>It was decided to investigate (digging, thickness measurements, metallurgical tests etc.) the failure points of the pipe-line according to a prioritization scale based on the level of importance of the failures identified.<br><br>The Departmental Directorate of Agriculture and Forests (DDAA) in charge of the environmental police performed the monitoring of the soil- and groundwater- pollution.<br><br>Moreover the operator has appointed a consultancy firm to:<br>- clean up the polluted ground without stopping the pipe-line activity<br>- decontaminate and dispose of the stored materials <br>- clean up of the polluted underground watershed<br><br>

Reasons.ItemDescription: Substances involved: greater than 5% of quantity in Column 3 of Annex I
Injury to persons: >= 1 fatalities, >= 6 hospitalizing injuries etc.
Immediate damage to the environment (according to Annex VI)

AccidentDescription:
The accident:

<br>A release of fuel oil and heating fuel occurred on the pipe-line connecting the coastal oil storage facility and the thermal power plant during supply operations of the power plant.

<br><br>The accident is classified at level 3 of the accident gravity scale due to the amount of released product (650 m3). This accident is worth being notified due to the  typology of the event (not exceptional) and the particular environmental conditions( effects of marine shore conditions on materials).
<br><br>The goal of the product transfer which started the accident on 18th September, was to replenish the on-site stock of the power plant.<br><br>On 18th September 2001, the presence of heavy fuel oil on the ground was observed in a corn-field at approximately 600 m from the hydrocarbon storage installation.<br><br>

Site_Description: The site and its context:<br>In the area of the municipality of Lucianna several industrial establishments need the supply of liquid and liquefied hydrocarbons for their operation. This is the case of the Electric power plant located inland and which is associated to a intermediate storage facility of 8000 m3 located on-shore and which acts as buffer for the fuel deliveries.<br>&nbsp;<b><br></b>
Installation_Description: The thermal power plant was put into service in 1975, the hydrocarbon pipe-line which supplies fuel to the plant from the coastal storage was put into service in 1975.<br><br>After delivery by sea tanker, the heavy fuel oil and the domestic fuel oil are first stored in the intermediate storage tank installation of the power plant operator located 1 km from the coast, then the fuel oil is transferred by pipeline in the storage facility of the power plant located 7,5 km inland from the coast; the pipe-line is buried under an average of 1 m of earth. Generally, the pipe-line is permanently filled with light fuel oil between two transfer phases.<br><br>The pipes are made out of 5,56 mm thick steel and have an internal section of 100 mm, the pipe-line is 7430 m long and is made of 12 m elements which are welded together at their ends. The pipe is covered with a 3 mm resin sleeve glued on the metal, a 5 cm insulation layer of polyurethane and finally another sleeve identical to the first one<br><br>The operating pressures are 40 bar for normal operation and 90 bar for forced operation in case of cooling of heavy fuel oil during decanting. The pipeline has been tested with 102 bar when it was put into service and during inspections every ten years.<br><br>The transfer procedure from the intermediate storage facility to the power station is the following one:<br><br>- pumping of light fuel-oil for 4 hours at 70° C and 10 bar in order to heat the pipe walls and avoid incrustations;<br>- pumping of the heavy fuel oil heated to 85° C with a starting pressure of 40 bar, the pressure drops to 36 bar during&nbsp; transfer operation when the pipe walls reach steady state temperature- <br>- pumping of "cold" light fuel oil at 20 bar to rinse the pipeline. <br><br>- filling of the pipeline with light fuel oil without any pressure between two transfer operations; in fact the pressure in the pipeline section towards the coast ( where the accident occurred) is&nbsp; approximately 2 bar. This static pressure is due to the level difference between the location of the power station and the coast (pressure column).<br><br>The transfer operations are performed by the personnel of the storage installation located near the intermediate storage facility which by contract is operated by the same personnel. When the storage facility is filled the power station has between 20 and 45 days of production supply depending on energy requests. <br>&nbsp;

Description: <b></b>The pipe-line was transferring heavy fuel oil when the accident happened<br><br>

Causes_Description: The pollution was caused by a leakage which occurred during the days preceding the detection of the release, a provisory repair was performed, the transfer operations of heavy fuel oil were performed from then on under increased control.<br><br>The programme set up to investigate the occurrence was organised as follows:<br>- visual investigation;<br>- chemical analysis;<br>- micrographic&nbsp; (microscopic); <br>- testing with an electronic micro-analyser probe.<br><br>The chemical analysis confirmed that the steel analysed corresponded to the specifications defined for constructing the pipe-line.<br><br>The micrographic test performed near the piercing showed a significant thickness reduction of the pipe wall and several corrosion points. It was found that at the level of the piercing point the material was torn. Several corrosion craters were also found outside the area around the piercing point.<br><br>On the other hand the presence of oxides on the external wall of the pipe and on the ripped borders makes it plausible that the leakage was not recent.<br><br>The tests with an electronic micro-analyser probe on the oxides found externally to the pipe-line wall showed the presence of chlorides.<br><br>These investigations led the operator to the following conclusions:<br>- the piercing of the pipe-wall was due to a significant loss of thickness of the pipe-walls;<br>- the generalised external corrosion of corresponding pipe-section was caused by chlorides; <br>- brackish water was present because of changes in the watershed-level and contamination of the water shed with sea water; <br>- and finally a localised failure of the pipe-protection <br>were the originating causes of the occurrence.<br><br>The assumption of the contamination of the watershed with sea-water was confirmed by the institution of hydro-geological experts of the Department of southern Corsica. Changes of the water-shed level were significant, rising several metres over a few days up to&nbsp; above ground level. <br>

CausesHumans.ItemDescription: operator health (includes ailments, intoxication, death, etc.)
wilful disobedience/failure to carry out duties

CausesExternals.ItemDescription: utilities failure (electricity, gas, water, steam air, etc.)

Consequence_Description: The investigations performed by the operator have shown<br><br>-&nbsp; soil pollution of the superficial earth layers with heavy fuel oil <br>-&nbsp; soil pollution with light fuel oil&nbsp; limited to the sandy areas of the underground, this kind of pollution was contained within the sandy layers by the presence of a considerable amount of compact turf<br>-&nbsp; pollution of the underground watershed localised to a limited area but potentially migrating at an unknown speed.<br><br>The amount of light fuel oil which infiltrated underground was estimated by the operator at 400 m3 to which the already recovered amount&nbsp; (250 m3) has to be added. The validity of this estimate is questionable due to the fact that it is unknown when exactly the spillage started.<br>
